Seer stared around his circle.  Each wore a hood making them 
indistinguish=
able.  On his left sat Deus, a heartless opportunist; 
in front of him sat =
Ex, a female bot who wished more than anything 
to know what the future hel=
d; and to his right was his most fearsome 
ally Machina, a warrior who want=
ed merely to live forever, and was 
willing to do whatever it took to break=
 the prophesy that doomed the 
three of them.

Seer, however, was under no =
such restraint.  He could not die, but 
nor could he leave his palace.  In =
it destiny energy flowed through 
him, he knew all possible pasts and prese=
nts, and most futures, and 
existed in all he could see.  Deus shuffled ner=
vously, he was 
planning a betrayal, and he knew Seer knew it, but he also =
knew that 
his betrayal was too small to bother with in retrospect of what =
Seer 
was trying to accomplish.  Deus' companion would die, but he would 
l=
ive=85for now.

	"The timelines are shifting wildly out of control," Seer 
=
said, opening the meeting.

	"Yes, but is it worth the risk to intervene an=
d try and stop 
it," said Machina.  He had never been able to see beyond ri=
sks, that 
was why he was destined to fail at his overall purpose.

	"We   =
will not stop it.  Because of this=85Neo Beast War the 
potential pasts and=
 presents are multiplying along with the future, 
but we must gain more des=
tiny potential in order to control it.  
Some presents are shifting away, b=
ecoming obscure.  Thankfully this 
course of events has provided us with an=
 ample source of potential.  
All actions in a past so distant are magnifie=
d in the present.  By 
stealing the potential of even one bot who vaguely r=
esembles a hero 
or villain we could very well achieve the equivalent of de=
stroying 
Optimus Prime."

	"Master, I volunteer for this service," said Ex=
.

	"No!" cut in Deus, "I-I mean in such a time period the 
destiny energy =
could magnify the potential for the prophesy of our 
demise being fulfilled=
.  We must send someone else."

	"Who else could be entrusted with such a t=
ask?" asked 
Machina.

	"I will personally vouch for Fortuneteller," said D=
eus with 
confidence.  All three of the other bots at the meeting burst int=
o 
laughter.

	"You would send one of our lowest level deviners?" asked Ex.=


	"And your lover at that," said Machina.

	Seer laughed for a moment with=
 them, but then considered the 
idea.  He called on his prescience, and saw=
 the potential for his 
own ends.  Fortuneteller might think she was workin=
g for Deus, but 
he knew he could make her do whatever he wanted in the end=
 with a 
few of Deus' screams if she refused to comply with his will.  "Ver=
y 
well!  She will go, and she will remember her prophesy `So long as 
you =
pay the Seer's price, no Transmetal will take your life.'  Now 
let us sele=
ct the target we can gain the most by destroying."


	Deus kissed her, and =
ran his fingers through her hair.  "I 
am yours," she said, "what do you wi=
sh me to do."

	"Go to Earth.  Bring me the destiny potential of the bot yo=
u 
have been ordered to kill.  Say he died before you got to him.  Only 
yo=
u, I, and Seer will know."

	"But Seer is the one who wants the destiny pot=
ential."

	"Yes, but he knows everything we've done against him, and 
hasn'=
t acted.  Obviously we're necessary to avoid some future he 
would prefer n=
ot to face.  We just need to keep working."

	"But I would break my prophes=
y, and lose my inability to be 
killed by transmetals."

	"Isn't it worth i=
t?  Isn't it worth it for me?"  He kissed 
her again.

	"Yes, my love.  Yes=
 is it."

OOC: O.k., I need a volunteer for Fortuneteller's quarry.
